title: Vancouver Is Marooned by Flooding and Besieged Again by Climate Change
content: After a summer of deadly heat and uncontrolled wildfires, British Columbia was hit by record rainfalls that forced the evacuation of towns and destroyed highways and rail lines.

more_info.byline: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai

title: In Hard Times, Afghan Farmers Are Turning to Opium for Security
content: The war’s intense conclusion and a drought combined to wipe out the famous Afghan pomegranate harvest in Kandahar Province, during a devastating national economic crisis.

more_info.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Taimoor Shah

title: Sick of the Status Quo, Chileans Head to the Polls
content: The top contenders to lead Chile out of a turbulent era are a leftist 35-year-old former student activist and a 55-year-old far-right former congressman, offering voters a stark choice.

more_info.byline: By Pascale Bonnefoy and Ernesto Londoño

title: Sudan’s Military Frees Prime Minister Held for Weeks After Coup
content: Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok returned to power under a deal intended to end a bloody standoff that has led to dozens of protester deaths since his ouster last month.

des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

title: Israeli Is Killed by Disguised Palestinian Near Holiest Site in Jerusalem
content: The shooting, the first attack by a Palestinian since May to result in the death of a Jewish civilian, could deepen tensions within Israel’s fragile governing coalition.

more_info.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Myra Noveck

title: As Pandemic Evictions Rise, Spaniards Declare ‘War’ on Wall Street Landlords
content: Protesters in Barcelona are pushing back against foreign investment firms that have bought up thousands of homes over the past decade and are forcing out residents who can’t pay the rent.

more_info.byline: By Nicholas Casey and Roser Toll Piraffé

title: As Soldiers Abandon Notorious Myanmar Army, a Morale Crisis Looms
content: The number of defectors, while not enough to topple the Tatmadaw, is growing, galvanized by the nationwide anti-coup movement.

des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

title: Videos Said to Be of Peng Shuai Don’t Resolve Questions About Her Safety
content: The editor of a state-run newspaper on Saturday shared clips said to be of the Chinese tennis star on Twitter. But they are unverified, and the head of the WTA called them “insufficient.”

more_info.byline: By Matthew Futterman and Christopher Clarey

title: How India’s Farmers, Organized and Well Funded, Faced Down Modi
content: They received foreign and domestic financial support, kept their camps organized and looked for ways to be seen while trying to avoid violence.

title: Hair Curlers in Public? That’s Just How They Roll.
content: The young South Korean women who wear them say they are not only functional, but also a sign of shifting ideas about beauty and a reflection of the country’s generational divide.

title: A Socialite, a Gardener, a Message in Blood: The Murder That Still Grips France
content: The victim was a socialite. A message in her blood accused the gardener. But a grammatical error raised questions of class and language — and whether he was being framed.

title: Covid Vaccine Gets Muted Welcome in Land Awash in Bigger Problems
content: Much of South Sudan is under water from flooding induced by climate change and deforestation. Crops and livestock are lost, hunger and malaria are spreading. With so many worries, coronavirus vaccines are a tough sell.

title: A Tabloid ‘Game of Thrones’ in London Could Tilt U.K. Politics
content: The top editor is out at The Daily Mail, widely viewed as the voice of middle-class voters, and the paper’s coverage of Boris Johnson’s government might be softened because of it.

title: Thousands in Austria Protest Virus Lockdown and Vaccine Mandate
content: The protests were largely peaceful, but as dusk fell over the Austrian capital, skirmishes broke out between officers and groups of demonstrators.

title: Playwright Is in Exile as Cuba Uses an Old Playbook to Quash Dissent
content: Yunior García, one of the rising stars of the Cuban protest movement, fled to Spain. He is one of a young generation of artists who say they have chosen exile over imprisonment.

title: Ardeshir Zahedi, Irrepressible Iranian Diplomat, Dies at 93
content: While he enabled business deals worth billions of dollars, he also hosted lavish parties, led conga lines through his embassy and dated Elizabeth Taylor.

title: More Asian countries slowly reopen their borders and welcome vaccinated travelers.
content: The easing of restrictions comes as the holiday travel season is about to begin.

title: How the U.S. Lost Ground to China in the Contest for Clean Energy
content: Americans failed to safeguard decades of diplomatic and financial investments in Congo, where the world’s largest supply of cobalt is controlled by Chinese companies backed by Beijing.

more_info.byline: By Eric Lipton, Dionne Searcey and Ashley Gilbertson

title: Mining Congo: A Global Power Play
content: The Democratic Republic of Congo has been a critical source of strategic minerals for the United States since at least World War II.

more_info.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Eric Lipton

title: Who, and Where, Is Peng Shuai?
content: A blackout within China on discussion of the tennis star’s #MeToo allegations has not been able to silence a global chorus of concern for her safety.

title: Just a few storms cloud the U.S. travel forecast for a second pandemic Thanksgiving.
Protests against Italy’s health pass fizzle.
content: A skimpy turnout for a rally in Rome and the outright failure of one in Milan underscored Italians’ overall acceptance of the country’s Green Pass.

title: Singapore will begin easing its Covid restrictions next week.
content: The Southeast Asian city state is recovering from a recent surge of hospitalizations. An official said its reopening would proceed in a “step-by-step manner.”

geo_facet: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

title: Race to the Future: What to Know About the Frantic Quest for Cobalt
content: A New York Times investigation examines the global demand for raw materials as the clean energy revolution takes off. This is what we found.

more_info.byline: By Eric Lipton, Dionne Searcey and Michael Forsythe

title: A Power Struggle Over Cobalt Rattles the Clean Energy Revolution
content: The quest for Congo’s cobalt, which is vital for electric vehicles and the worldwide push against climate change, is caught in an international cycle of exploitation, greed and gamesmanship.

more_info.byline: By Dionne Searcey, Michael Forsythe, Eric Lipton and Ashley Gilbertson

title: Beaver Dams Mean No Love Lost for Canada’s Emblematic Animal
content: Blamed for flooded fields, damaged roads and the occasional death, the beaver, which has played a seminal role in Canadian history, is now viewed by many as a problem, not a point of national pride.

title: How Hunter Biden’s Firm Helped Secure Cobalt for the Chinese
content: The president’s son was part owner of a venture involved in the $3.8 billion purchase by a Chinese conglomerate of one of the world’s largest cobalt deposits. The metal is a key ingredient in batteries for electric vehicles.

more_info.byline: By Michael Forsythe, Eric Lipton and Dionne Searcey

title: How Are Electric Vehicle Batteries Made?
content: The worldwide shift to electric vehicles is critical in the fight against climate change. Here's how the most important part of these cars is made.

more_info.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Eric Lipton

title: Thousands rally against coronavirus restrictions in Australia.
content: Demonstrators gathered in cities around the country to protest vaccine mandates and other rules.

title: A Cold and Snowy Match Leaves Canada’s Soccer Team in an Unexpected Spot
content: The Canadian men’s team, which has not been in the World Cup since 1986, is now leading the regional qualifying competition.

title: Canada expands its list of vaccines accepted for travel.
content: Officials also removed a test requirement for eligible travelers re-entering Canada within 72 hours.

title: Amazon Deforestation Soars to 15-Year High
content: Brazil committed this month to end illegal deforestation in eight years, but a government report raises questions about its intent and ability to meet that target.

des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
